mappedQuestions.reasoning: Question describes a student with slow reading speed but high accuracy and asks for the appropriate intervention (Repeated readings for fluency).
Question asks to identify the stage of learning (Acquisition) when a student is just learning a new skill and needs immediate feedback.
Question asks for an example of an evidence-based intervention for reading comprehension (Reciprocal teaching/Question generation).
Question asks to select the appropriate intensity of support (Tier 2) for a student slightly below benchmark.
Question asks for the best strategy to improve math fact fluency (Timed drills/Cover-Copy-Compare) vs. reasoning.
Question asks for a strategy to help students monitor their own learning and thinking processes (Metacognition/Self-monitoring).
Question asks specifically for the accuracy range that defines the 'Instructional Level' (93-97% or 70-85% depending on text type in question).
Question asks for the appropriate instructional focus for a student who has mastered accuracy but lacks speed (Proficiency/Fluency building).
Question involves analyzing error patterns to identify the specific skill deficit before planning instruction.
Question asks to identify Direct Instruction characteristics (Scripted, fast-paced, high response rate).
Question asks for strategies to support executive function/organization in academic tasks (Graphic organizers/Planners).

suggestedNewSkills.name: Instructional Hierarchy Application
suggestedNewSkills.description: Match instructional strategies to the student's stage of learning (Acquisition, Proficiency/Fluency, Generalization, Adaptation).
suggestedNewSkills.decisionRule: Correct answer matches: Acquisition → Modeling/Accuracy; Proficiency → Speed/Drill; Generalization → New settings.

suggestedNewSkills.name: Metacognitive & Study Skills
suggestedNewSkills.description: Identify strategies that teach students 'learning to learn' (self-regulation, organization, mnemonic devices).
suggestedNewSkills.decisionRule: Correct answer focuses on the student's internal management of learning (thinking about thinking) rather than content mastery.
